Identifying Characteristics: Spire of the shell is elongated and the body whorl rounded
Aperature length is greater than the width
Shell is light yellowish-olive to olive colored and can have deposits of tan, brown, or rust
Newborn young have an opaque white or light translucent beige shell
Has an operculum with concentric rings radiating from center
Biology: Mating usually takes place in the warmer months of the year
Diet: Can also graze and harvest deposits on soft sediments
Habitat: Sandy bottoms where the current is sufficient to oxygenate the water column (especially in the larger rivers of the Piedmont and upper Coastal Plain)
Usually found around decaying organic matter, and burrows in the substrate
Range: Eastern North American - Canada to Florida
